text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in the Danish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

--Supermarket chain FDB wants to allow the 1.2 million members of its customer-loyalty programme to borrow and deposit money, converting their exisiting mebership card to a form of credit and payment card.
--Parliament has voted to ban the cloning of adult animals.
--Social Democrat mayors are warning Finance Minister and party colleague Mogens Lykketoft to impose excessive budgetary restrictions on local authorities.

--The liquidation of a state insurance fund for losses to shipping through war could take until 1998 before the state receives its 2.3 billion crown share, strengthening the government's hand in 1998 budget negotiations.

--Up to 800 planned business alliances have been banned under new competition rules, although most of those outstanding are expected to receive special dispensations. Among the projects in question is an alliance between BG Bank, mortgage-lender Nykredit and insurance company Topdanmark.
--Cleaning and service company ISS is at an advanced stage in negotiations with Skovbo local council, west of Copenhagen, to set up the first ISS-managed kindergarten.
--Den Danske Bank has shelved staff cutbacks planned for the second half of 1997 because of increased business activity.
